headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: The First Lady talks about Running in 2024; Best Films at Box Office; New Trend of Bare Minimum Monday. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN, FIRST LADY
utterances.sentences: Was this recently?

utterances.speaker: ARLETTE SAENZ, CNN WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: It was recent.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Oh. I must have missed it.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: So we're going to the source.Where do things stand? When's an announcement coming?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, he said he intends to run. So, nothing's been planned yet. I think, you know, he's been so busy with being in Ukraine, handling some of the crises at home. So, I - I think, you know, he's not -- he's putting that first. He's putting America's business before he's putting his own.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: But has the decision been made amongst the family that he's going to run?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, it's Joe's -- really it's Joe's decision. And we support whatever he wants to do. If he's in, we're there. If he wants to do something else, we're there, too.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Is there any chance at this point that he's not going to run?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Not in my book.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: You're all for it?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I'm all for it, of course.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: So, as we're reading all of these tea leaves, this is just another indication that the president is moving closer to launching a possible re-election bid. Of course, his advisers have pointed to the coming months as a possible launch date for that.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: And you spent time with the first lady, as I said in the introduction to you, as she traveled through Africa. Tell us more about that. That's interesting.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Yes, we spent the last five days traveling through Africa, stops in Namibia and Kenya, where the first lady really talked about a host of issues, including women's empowerment, the importance of young people in democracy, and also talking about some of the government programs that have aided Africa, including PEPFAR, which is celebrating its 20th anniversary.But perhaps the most poignant moment came yesterday when she traveled down to rural -- a rural village in Kenya to see firsthand the impact of drought in the region. There were hundreds gathered there to receive health and nutritional services. And the first lady got to hear firsthand what these people were experiencing. And we were there every step of the way and we'll bring -- be bringing that to you a little bit later this week.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wow, interesting. Thank you so much. I don't know if you guys have gotten - Arlette, we're going to - we'll be watching your special.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Can't wait to see that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But if you've ever gone to Africa and gotten to see what PEPFAR does, it is astounding. It was astounding what the power of a United States president, what it - what it can do.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's a great point.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: By the way, you can watch the rest of Arlette's wide-ranging interview with First Lady Jill Biden. CNN primetime, "Jill Biden

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Can't wait to watch that.And for more on what Jill Biden told Arlette there, let's bring CNN's chief political correspondent and the co-anchor of "STATE OF THE UNION," Dana Bash. Dana, anyone who has ever covered Biden knows that the probably biggest influence on his decisions is the first lady. So, what she says there carries a lot of weight about what we could see happen with his 2024 run.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, he's definitely running.

utterances.speaker: DANA BASH, CNN CHIEF POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Definitely, unless he's not.First of all, good morning, guys. Nice to see you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Good morning.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Good morning.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Not only does she carry like the ultimate weight, but the other thing that you all know from covering Joe Biden for a long time is that he's not generally in a rush to make decisions, especially big, consequential decisions, which is part of the reason why it's taking as long in the view of some Democrats as it is. I'll tell you what I'm hearing from sources in Biden world. And thatis the following. Just like you just heard from the first lady, he's been very focused on all of the international trips and policy that he's needed to focus on as the year anniversary of Ukraine approached. And just on the raw politics of it, they (INAUDIBLE) is not likely to have a significant primary challenger. There's no rush to jump in. They look at the calendar and the history, the most recent history of a two-term president, and that is his former boss, Barack Obama, that he didn't announce until around now. The thing that is missing, as far as we know, though, is the kind of behind-the-scenes movement that generally happens, or the sort of checking out of the White House and checking into a political world from people who are close to him. We haven't seen that happen yet. And that is a bit surprising.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Is it because - though I feel like he's taking sort of the diplomatic road rather than the traditional, I'm going to run for president road (ph) because he's using it as - you know, traveling to Ukraine and what have you. And maybe that's his best bet right now is that, hey, look, I'm in charge and I'm leading already.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes, that's exactly right. That's exactly right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You had a really enlightening, I thought, eye-opening interview with the RNC chair, Ronna McDaniel, after her fourth, you know, win to lead that yesterday. And this exchange was striking about whether they will, again, call for a loyalty pledge for the eventual nominee.Listen -- I want our viewers to hear this and get your thoughts on the other side. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RONNA MCDANIEL, RNC CHAIR
utterances.sentences: We haven't put the criteria out, but I expect a pledge will be part of it. It was part of 2016. I think it's kind of a no-brainer, right? If you're going to be on the Republican National Committee debate stage, asking voters to support you, you should say, I'm going to support the voters and who they choose as the nominee. BASHa couple of weeks ago in an interview with conservative radio host Hugh Hewitt on this very topic.

utterances.speaker: HUGH HEWITT
utterances.sentences: If you're not the nominee, will you support whoever the GOP nominee is?DONALD TRUMP, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT: It would depend. I would - I would give you the same answer I gave in 2016 during the debate, it would have to depend on who the nominee was.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: So are you prepared to block the former president if he doesn't sign it?

utterances.speaker: MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: Well, he signed it in 2016. He did.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: Everybody signed it in 2016.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But this is about the here and the now. He didn't commit to it.

utterances.speaker: MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think they're - I think they're all going to sign it. I really do.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: She really -- remember when she said to you at the beginning of the interview, I ran on a unity platform. She really sounds like she believes it, unity, it's going to be recall good, everyone on the same page. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I think that is definitely her goal. I've heard from at least one potential candidate after that, concerned that in her - in her effort to create unity among the candidates, by asking them, forcing them to sign a pledge in order to get on the debate stage -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: It will inherently cause fracture. Because of the other thing that I talked to her about, which is the elephant, no pun intended, in the room, which is the fact that we're talking about the former president here. And we're talking about a former president who has been disqualified from being president again in the eyes of several potential candidates for president. And the feeling is, among some of them, how can I sign a pledge promising to support him as the nominee if he is the nominee if I don't think he should be president.And it's going to be a very tough thing for some of these candidates who are going to have to decide, from their perspective, if they are going to put country first or party first. And that is kind of the calculus that is going on. Not among all of the Republican candidates who are not Donald Trump, but among some of them. Never mind the question that I've put in the clip that you played about Trump himself, whether he will actually stick to any kind of pledge. They signed pledges in 2016. It's not really clear that they actually lived up to it. I mean John Kasich signed that pledge to get on the debate stage and he never supported Donald Trump. Just one example.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's a great point that it's not just about Trump and what he does, it's also what Asa Hutchinson and others.One fascinating part of this interview, I think, was where she brought up the fact that she's Mitt Romney's niece. Something that we saw her downplay at times. And she said, I'm Mitt Romney's niece. I was appointed to the RNC by Trump. She goes, I would support both of them if they were the nominee, but I don't know if they would support each other. Talk about how damaging all of this is for Republicans, generally, that they're not -- that they don't know for sure that they'd support who the nominee is.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes, I really thought that was interesting, as well, because she was trying to make the point that she is a unifier and she is somebody who can kind of see broadly on the entire Republican spectrum.But look, again, it is damaging because we're talking about the influence of one man, and that is Donald Trump. If Donald Trump were not part of this equation and you're talking about Ron DeSantis, Asa Hutchinson, Chris Sununu, you know, Chris Christie, name your candidate, they would all be fine with signing a loyalty pledge. This is about Donald Trump, events of January 6th, full stop.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The Trump campaign said they (INAUDIBLE) don't have to worry about this because they think he's going to be the nominee.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: He will be.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Dana Bash, fascinating interviews, as always. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Thanks, guys. Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Love the sweater look, Dana. It looks great.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: She always does. Did you see her glowing in white yesterday? Just come here for your compliments.All right, one -- Harry thought that was funny. Thanks, Harry. One film swept last night's SAG Awards, but did anyone actually go to the theater to see it? I can't wait to see it. Kaitlan saw it. Harry Enten is here to break it down.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And I saw it in theater.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Not a lot of people -(COMMERCIAL BREAK) [08:43:53] (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And the actor goes to "Everything, Everywhere, All at Once."(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK, so "Everything, Everywhere, All at Once" seemed to win, well, everything at the SAG Awards, but did you pay to see it in theaters? It begs the question, are award shows really out of touch? The question is, too, Harry, where can you even watch the award shows?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right, you were saying that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I was saying like I was trying to watch the Image Awards, didn't know where I could watch it. Watch the SAG Awards, didn't know where I could watch them. So, if you can't watch the awards and watch the movie -- I don't know.

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: You need - you need a - you need a TV Guide, Don.But, look --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's not on TV!

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: No, (INAUDIBLE) streaming!

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: So, where do Oscar best picture films rank at domestic box office in a given year? Since 2009, look at these nominations. 62nd! That has been the median rank. 62nd! Compare that to 1980 to 2008, where they ranked 11th. So it seems to me that the Oscars have this almost ballooning problem whereby it used to be - look, it wasn't that they'd win the best picture - the best picture - best picture film would be in the top of the box office, but at least be near the top. That's not the case anymore.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK, so, do people even go to the movies anymore?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes. SO, here's the thing, though, do people actually go to the movies anymore.Saw a movie in the theater last week. Look, in 1950, 33 percent of Americans saw a movie in the last week.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Look at that. Wow.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: But look at this trend, 10 percent in '68, 8 percent in '95, 3 percent in 2013. In 2022, just 2 percent of Americans saw a movie in the last week. And compare that to streaming or being on TV - or -- yes, look at this. Watch a movie at least once in the last week via paid streaming, look at that, 58 percent of Americans watched at least one movie per week via paid streaming. Look at paid TV, 52 percent. So a majority of Americans are still watching movies, but they're watching it, in fact, on their television. They're not going to the movies and watching it in person.Of course, I do have to ask the question, what is video entertainment anymore anyway? Because we have YouTube, about 65 percent of adults and 90 percent of teens use it more than once weekly. And we have TikTok, which is even shorter, right? About 25 percent of adults and 65 percent of teens use it more than weekly. So, I'm not sure box office really tells us much anymore anyway, guys.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I'm YouTube -- I watch a lot of YouTube TV.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You do?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. And very rarely do I -

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: It's good stuff.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You went to the movies on Friday, though?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But that counts.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: My husband goes, I wish we could be watching something else. We don't get time to go to adult movies. But, yes, it sort of counts.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's not easy with kids.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It sort of counts. Yes, right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Harry Enten.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Harry.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, sir. Thanks, Harry.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Do you suffer from the Sunday scaries? Well, a new TikTok trend aims to put an end to the suffering. We'll tell you about bare minimum Monday, coming up.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy. HARLOW

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Here for it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, Damian Lillard has developed a reputation during his 11-year NBA career in Portland. It's called Dame time. And last night the Houston Rockets felt the full force of it as the seven-time all-star scoring 71 points last night. Yes, 71 points in that game. He was scoring at will from inside, outside, way outside, from the logo at half court at one point. Lillard became just the eighth player in the NBA's history with at least 70 points in a game. He is the oldest to ever do it at the very young age of 32. Here's Dame after the game.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DAMIAN LILLARD, PORTLAND TRAIL BLAZERS GUARD
utterances.sentences: We got I think 23, 22 games left after this. And we need to win as many as possible. And you know, obviously, being shorthanded, I know that it's going to be a team effort, but I feel like I've got to, you know, do my best to be aggressive and just try to do what I can to make sure that we get some wins in. you know, that's all the case was, was tonight. I wanted to be in attack mode. I got it going and I just stayed aggressive.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: He was definitely in attack mode. He was definitely aggressive. Lillard led the Blazers to their 29th win as they are trying to break into the playoffs, as he noted there. Down to the final stretch of the season. Awesome game.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Loved that!

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Dame time.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Love this next one. Can you relate to this? Watch.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I got to get out of here. I think I'm going to lose it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Uh-oh! Sounds like somebody's got a case of the Mondays!(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well, according to a new TikTok trend, Mondays should actually be about doing almost nothing, as little as possible, and not feeling bad about it. This is something called bare minimum Monday.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You knew it was time for something new. So one Monday last year, you woke up and gave yourself permissioned to do the absolute bare minimum for work that day. And everything felt different. The pressure was gone, your work was easier, and you felt better.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Our chief business correspondent Christine Romans is with us, who knows - you know nothing about bare minimum Monday.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, the irony of the four of us talking about this at 8

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I know. Right.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN CHIEF BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: It's a thing. It's a real thing on TikTok. And there are a lot of young workers who are saying, look, the Sunday scares turn into this unproductive, anxiety- ridden Monday. Monday is the least favorite workday of the week. And so they're focusing on a little bit of self-care. They're easing out of the weekend and into the week and saying they're going to do the very bare minimum.It's the latest in, remember, quiet quitting. There's also something called rage applying, which is where you are ostensibly at work but you're actually applying to millions of different job offers and they're - or job openings. And there's cyber loafing, where you look like you're busy at work, but really you're using the company time and material for, you know, doing your own personal stuff, which I have actually signed my kids up for camps before at work, but that's because I was working like a 15-hour day.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I mean, come on, you also like work in the middle of the night and -

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: I know. I know. But, listen, I asked a workplace culture expert, you know, is this just slacking? What are bosses supposed to think about this? This is actually going out there saying, I'm going to work less, and this is what she told me.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JESSICA KRIEGEL, CHIEF SCIENTIST OF WORKPLACE CULTURE, CULTURE PARTNERS
utterances.sentences: I would say that those CEOs and those bosses who are rolling their eyes, that sometimes we have to set aside what is urgent in order to focus on what's important. And that is what bare minimum Mondays is trying to accomplish.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: I mean, remember Garfield?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Are we - are we gen-x?

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: I hate Monday. I'm gen-x. You're -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What am I?

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Are you - you're gen-x. You're gen-x.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Gen-x.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: So I'm just saying that, every generation has their like reevaluation - I hate -- Garfield said it best, he's way before TikTok, and he already hated Mondays.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I worked weekends for a long time and I had Mondays off. It was the best thing ever. And I know -

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: You had to work during the weekend.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. And then the late schedule, I never had the Sunday scares, because I didn't have to be at work until 10

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The Sunday scares are real.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I love that phrase because it really is like this collective anxiety that people feel on Sundays.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Yes. It is. It is. But I wonder -- I think it also all reflects how we don't know who has the upper hand in the economy right now. Last hour I was telling you how confusing everything is. Are the bosses in charge? Are the workers in charge? I mean, it's really fascinating where we are right now.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I get excited all day Sunday to see you guys. So, you know, that's just me.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Poppy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It's -- I'm not lying. Happy bare minimum -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Have a Bible, I'm going to put your hand on that Bible because I don't -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Happy bare minimum Monday. Where's a Bible.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I do not believe that.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Christine Romans.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: You're welcome.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: See you guys tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Have a great day.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What's Tuesday called?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: CNN "NEWSROOM" starts after -

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: What is Tuesday?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You've got to go full force on Tuesday.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Tuesday, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I don't know.
